title: Locket, 1899–1908
medium: Yellow gold (18 kt), white gold (18 kt), enamel, diamonds
markings: Under one locket opening: "A*H" (Cyrillic) for August Hollming, and with St. Petersburg 1899-1908 assay mark for assay master A. Richter.
provenance: Lorey Katz; 2004: bequested to the Museum
description: Quatrefoil shape with square projections, the top engine-turned under white enamel centered by a .50 kt round old mine cut diamond and surrounded by approximately .75 kts of rose-cut diamonds; opening to reveal two circular locket compartments in yellow gold; with gold and diamond bail. Together with a white gold chain.
justification:
From Acquisition Justification:
"This is a good example of the use of enamel in Fabergé jewelry.&nbsp;&nbsp; This piece is marked by&nbsp; Faberge&nbsp; workmaster August Fredrick Hollming ( 1854-1913.&nbsp; Hollming had the right to sign objects with his initials.&nbsp; Born in Finland, he was a workmaster in St. Petersburg from 1880 until his death.&nbsp; He produced gold and silver boxes, some enamelled and, occasionally, some enamelled jewelry, of which this is a fine example.&nbsp; The quality of the central diamond is high,&nbsp; which is appropriate.&nbsp; This piece augments and compliments Fabergé gold iris pendant (1995-15-6), enamel pendant egg (1995-15-2), and gold and jeweled brooch (1995-15-5) in collection.&nbsp; The shape of the pendant relates closely to recently discovered and published drawings from the St. Petersburg Archives.&nbsp; The enamelled back centered by a diamond and surrounded by a band of small band of diamonds is similar to that of a well-exhibited and published watchcase produced by Faberge during the same period.&nbsp;&nbsp; This piece demonstrates high quality use of engine-turning under enamel, relating to the techniques of snuffboxes produced in Switzerland and France in the late 18th and early 19th centuries."

tombstone.epitaph: Locket, 1899–1908.Yellow gold (18 kt), white gold (18 kt), enamel, diamonds. Bequest of Lorey Katz. 2004-12-1.
